Even and odd functions

We have shown in a previous Section how to calculate, by integration, the coefficients \(a_n\) (\(n = 0, 1, 2, 3, \dots\)) and \(b_n\) (\(n = 1, 2, 3, \dots\)) in a Fourier series. Clearly this is a somewhat tedious process and it is advantageous if we can obtain as much information as possible without recourse to integration. Also in a previous Section we showed that the square wave (one period of which shown in the Figure below) has a Fourier series containing a constant term and cosine terms only (i.e. all the Fourier coefficients \(b_n\) are zero).




 Alternatively the function shown below has a more complicated Fourier series containing both cosine and sine terms as well as a constant.


One can see that the square (shown first) wave has a graph which is symmetrical about the \(y\)-axis and is called an even function. The saw-tooth wave (shown second) has no particular symmetry.

In general a function is called even if its graph is unchanged under reflection in the \(y\)-axis. This is equivalent to \[ f(-t) = f(t) \hspace{0.5cm} \text{for all} \hspace{0.3cm} t\] Obvious examples of even functions are \(t^2\), \(t^4\), \(\lvert t \rvert \), \(\cos t\), \(\cos^2 t\), \(\sin^2 t\), \(\cos nt\).

A function is said to be odd if its graph is symmetrical about the origin (i.e. it has rotational symmetry about the origin). This is equivalent to the condition \[ f(-t) = -f(t)\] The Figure below shows an example of an odd function.



Examples of odd functions are \(t\), \(t^3\), \(\sin t\), \(\sin nt\). A periodic function which is odd is the saw-tooth wave in the Figure below.



Some functions are neither even nor odd. The periodic saw-tooth wave (second Figure from top) is an example; another is the exponential function \(e^t\).
